Nonetheless, in that time the Colors kept
their own purity, lacking none,
while they could not be seen.

4. To speak of this further: I believe
that the colors, as we have always seen them,
are all revealed by and have the nature of
the four Elements, hard or soft,
when the Sun shines on them, or where the light falls.
However, one might well ask what is color itself,
which, in its various manifestations,
Is constituted from the four Elements.

5. Color is, in itself, the external visibility
of a body to which it belongs,
while yet being the substance of light;
because the troubling darkness, by its thickness,
prevents the eye utterly from perceiving difference;
while daylight in particular grants vision the gift
of clearly distinguishing, without error,
how each color is constituted.
left-middleDaylight is the most suitable for distinguishing Colors.

6. The clarity of light, after Darkness disperses,
brings out the beauty of Colors.
Then, the powers and virtues of Colors are revealed,
for there is nothing, no matter how unimportant,
which does not have its color. And finally, in sum:
nothing can exist without color,
whatever its nature, even strange,
and all colors are built on the foundation of the visible.
left-middleNo visible thing is without color.

7. There are two sorts of color
(according to the insight of Pliny)
despite the number of pigments:
that is, natural, and those made with art.
The natural [ones] are named after the Countries
where one can find them; reciting all these names
would be easier to desire than to do,
and the list would be far from complete.
left-middleThere are two kinds of Colors, natural and artificial.

8. Color, the particular natural quality
of all things, whether still or moving,
is the topmost garment and outermost covering,
whether it be single colored, mixed, or multicolored.
Many things have the name of a color;
they provoke and satisfy that hungry look

9. Color can reveal the differences among things,
such as clearly distinguishing Gold from Bronze;
Color makes persons bold or frightened,
